I'm doing an IBD of master, with -dbcache=6000, and see "[warning] Flushing large (1 GiB) UTXO set to disk, it may take several minutes" every 8s. Current cache=1100mb or so. Is this normal?
(when that log line appears theres a ~2 second pause)
sample output: https://gist.github.com/fanquake/02dd156b2970b6c6565032a19c22d935
That's a pruned node, right?
Yes. Started with -prune=550
Fixed in #33512
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33512 | coins: use number of dirty cache entries in flush warnings/logs by l0rinc · Pull Request #33512 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
The pruned node flushes a lot, but only dirty entries are written. The warnings get logged because there's a large cache of clean entries.
Flushing every ~150 blocks seems a bit excessive?
It's 48 hours of blocks at 550 I believe, so not really.
My dumb maths is saying this will add 3 hours to IBD?
If every flush takes ~2 seconds
There's a relevant issue https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/30037
[bitcoin] maflcko opened pull request #34276:  Remove empty caption from ThreadSafeMessageBox  (master...2601-less-gui-kernel) https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34276
Increase prune size and it should be faster.
Also see #31845
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/31845 | Add -pruneduringinit option to temporarily use another prune target during IBD by luke-jr · Pull Request #31845 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
fanquake: it was even slower before #28280, but now at least you don't get hit with the read penalty after each flush.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/28280 | Don't empty dbcache on prune flushes: >30% faster IBD by andrewtoth · Pull Request #28280 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
heh, re #34145 i could have sworn we had a test for a CHECKMULTISIG with a missing dummy element
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34145 | test: Add unit tests for OP_NUMEQUALVERIFY and OP_CHECKMULTISIG by billymcbip · Pull Request #34145 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub

We do have https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/62557c95298d88be8920c1b3b952d07d0aedb1af/src/test/data/tx_invalid.json#L83-L86 but it must be failing on some other check since the coverage report is not picking it up https://maflcko.github.io/b-c-cov/total.coverage/src/script/interpreter.cpp.gcov.html#L1199

sipa have you given any thought to having some logging when txgraph reports a non-optimal graph (say after a DoWork) to track if it happens. I guess what would be useful for diagnostics?
instagibbs: i hadn't really thought about that, but for debugging that seems useful
not as a default log level though
right, mempool topic only
topic, or label, whatever we call them

For the instance in Apply() I think it could make sense just to say it ended up being non-optimal, and based on how many times you see this log you along with other mempool messages can probably reconstruct a cluster and reason about how much time was spent?

sigh
txgraph tracks whether clusters are optimal too, so it could expose it, making it RPC-queryable?
sighing at the spam not you
yeah I think DoWork(0) is literally this
in round about way
(if we know were not oversized which we should not be at call sites we have)
ah right, but DoWork() doesn't tell you which cluster is suboptimal
true, knowing which one then being able to query it would be nice
vs reconstructing from logs and data mining

l0rinc: it would be good to know more about your expectations here. Should the CI pass when run somewhere that doesn't have the hardware to run it?
If we added 10x the CPU to the main repo tomorrow, and expanded the number of tasks, and added heavier tasks, then more things would also fail in forks, without the extra hardware.

I don't really see how to avoid that, without unnecessarily containing the main repo (based on some vague/possibly changing external requirements), or providing every contributor with the same hardware.
(and I think we should be trying to expand the CI in the main repo, and add more jobs).
I think we should be running as many tests, as fast as possible, and tuning timeouts/expectations around that. Not optimising for what might be happening outside the repo.

Starting with the WGs!
#topic Fuzzing WG Update (dergoegge)

Eugene has been working on incremental snapshot support for fuzzamoto (https://github.com/dergoegge/fuzzamoto/pull/103). This will hopefully, in the long run, enable the fuzzer to explore even deeper into the state space.

I've open sourced the continuous fuzzing infra I've been running for the past years: https://github.com/dergoegge/fuzzor (there are no docs, but let marcofleon or me know if you want to run this as well)

We've found a bunch of bugs using antithesis (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20author%3Adergoegge%20antithesis) (it's only been a week, i'll have more to say on this later/next coredev but lmk if there are questions).

BIP style

#topic Net Split WG Update (cfields)
Murch[m] I meant per block

No net split update this week. But I did manage to track down and work around the gcc bug slowing down the chacha20 impl that l0rinc mentioned here last week: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=107563#c13

For anyone wondering why I'm spending _so_ much time on chacha20, it's because I'm hoping to prove that writing generic vectorized code like this is a reasonable way forward for us for our low-level bottlenecks. If so, we could be more liberal with adding simd code as it's easier to review than bare asm.
(not seeing the cluster people, feel free to speak up if there is something to share otherwise moving on in a few sec)
#topic Constant build failures on forked repos since introduction of `Valgrind fuzz` CI job (l0rinc)

The Valgrind fuzz job was introduced in e4b04630bcf59ea03c1373777a0167af699f92a4. Since then, ci/test/00_setup_env_native_fuzz_with_valgrind.sh seems to regularly time out on forked repositories (which fall back to GitHub-hosted runners), hitting the 240 minute job timeout, see: l0rinc/bitcoin/actions/runs/21003573850/job/60381011678
I first tried bumping the timeout to the GitHub Actions maximum, since the run took 4h 36m 50s.
maflcko suggested that we rather remove it from the CI matrix since it didn't reveal anything (similarly to how the valgrind no-fuzz task is handled) - which was rejected by others, see: #34304
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34304 | ci: remove `Valgrind fuzz` from CI matrix by l0rinc · Pull Request #34304 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub

Being able to run CI on forked repositories was working before #33461, it's useful to have a playground available to validate CI passing before we push to bitcoin/bitcoin - to avoid people pushing to bitcoin/bitcoin and experimenting there.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33461 | ci: add Valgrind fuzz by fanquake · Pull Request #33461 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
It's fine if certain heavy tasks are skipped on GitHub-hosted runners, but we shouldn't get used to red CI on forks, and we should make sure bitcoin/bitcoin isn't the only green build.
I posted my thoughts above, before the meeting, but can copy them back here
It would be good to know more about your expectations here. Should the CI pass when run somewhere that doesn't have the hardware to run it?
If we added 10x the CPU to the main repo tomorrow, and expanded the number of tasks, and added heavier tasks, then more things would also fail in forks, without the extra hardware.

I don't really see how to avoid that, without unnecessarily constraining the main repo (based on some vague/possibly changing external requirements), or providing every contributor with the same hardware.
could it be fixed by having the job respect some RUN_SLOW_CHECKS variable that is only set in the main repo?
(rember than GH CI in forks only works because GH gives away CPU for free, for now)
I think we should be running as many tests, as fast as possible, and tuning timeouts/expectations around that. Not optimising for what might be happening outside the repo.
yes, that was an alternative that willcl-ark also suggested
hi
fanquake: +1. It seems the fact that CI can run in forked repos is just a byproduct of our CI configuration still being quite light compared to the size/importance of the project.
thus isn't an optimization, I just want to restore the build passing outside of bitcoin/bitcoin
If someone wants to run the CI on a raspberry Pi, when shouldn't be optimising for that
*we
Investigating some RUN_SLOW_CHECKS variable seems like the best option, I can totally see that GH changes their policies in the future and this option goes away
Seems like there is nothing to add to the conversation for now. sipa: Did you want to say something about cluster mempool?
cluster mempool update: #34259 got merged; i've marked #34257 as next to review. Since it's more than an implementation, I'm curious about more conceptual opinions on the matter too.
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34259 | Find minimal chunks in SFL by sipa · Pull Request #34259 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/34257 | txgraph: deterministic optimal transaction order by sipa · Pull Request #34257 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
(and thanks for the review, we're in the home stretch)
Thanks for the updates everyone! Anything else to discuss?
just a small add to the SP convo

Novo: l0rinc was asking for entire chain scanning. Just to add an answer for it: for now, the focus has been on adversarial scenarios (at least on libsecp), mostly the worst case for a single block. Outcomes of this obviously improve the overall scanning time as well, but the happy path has not been part of this first "let's do not introduce a DoS vector" step.
that's it.

sipa: the discussion in #33335 is convincing that a deterministic tie breaker is preferable. But i find it quite unintuitive that between two equal-feerate transactions you would choose to pick the one that pays a miner less. Miners optimize for maximum fees, which often (though not always) means maximizing feerate first, but also just absolute

fees? Now i understand miners optimize for what actually ends up paying them, which is what they can actually pack in a template, and that sometimes smaller transactions can lead to higher-paying templates, but is that the common case?
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33335 | txgraph: randomize order of same-feerate distinct-cluster transactions by sipa · Pull Request #33335 · bitcoin/bitcoin · GitHub
darosior: it's important to note that this is just choosing the order of chunks within a group of equal-feerate ones - and that group has fixed size, and fixed total fee
so it's just a question of where to put the boundaries between chunks in it, and it's really the distance between where the block boundary falls and the last chunk boundary before it that matters
And more often than not you'd want to have the smaller transaction first because the larger (higher-fee) one would not fit and therefore if you didn't order this way you'd give up both their fees?
spells out loud to make sure he understands
[bitcoin] hebasto opened pull request #34310: iwyu: Add missed line to IWYU patch (master...260115-iwyu-patch) https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34310

[bitcoin] b-l-u-e opened pull request #34311: test: add unit tests for wallet interface getter basic method (master...test-wallet-interfaces-getter-coverage) https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34311
darosior: no, i don't think it matters either way - the only reason to prefer smaller is because people deliberately grinding for smaller size feels "not really bad"
we just can't predict where the boundaries will fall

maybe in a world where there is a permanent transaction backlog, and many transactions that just never get mined, smaller first is actually better because you can have clusters whose ends never make it
but i don't think this is an important point... the real "quality" aspect is covered by picking higher feerate first, and splitting up chunks in minimal parts
the rest is just convention to get determinism

On the other hand choosing on the contrary the highest-fee-paying one may directly solve the "grinding" since it would mean just paying for more block space which someone can already do if they want to. But yeah it's probably never going to matter either way.
yeah, fair point - i can see an argument for largest size first too

<fjahr> "Matt Corallo: Have you considere..." <- probably more likely gitea than gitlab, looks cleaner and much simpler to self-host, but I'm wayyyyy more excited to use something that has built-in cryptographic authentication and redundancy than just go self-host a github replacement.
I already hate enough that ACKs aren't in any way authenticated aside from "github says they came from someone with the right cookie"
something where you can do reviews offline and sync them later natively is also a really cool win for devs that want it (but requiring it for everyone to open an issue wouldn't really be okay)
in theory radicle looks like nearly exactly what i want from a "source forge" (as they call it), except for the above issues
it looks designed for a situation where every contributor runs their own radicle node, so you can use node key as user identifier, and give permission based on those?
but it sounds like you're looking for something with a more social aspect, where external contributors can interact with the project too
sipa: yes, there appears to be a proposed spec to disentangle the node-id from the person doing the action, so that you can use the same identity across devices.
from there, it seems like a relatively simple leap to have a web ui that allows people to create identities and just interact via a web interface
I don't care toooo much if people can open PRs without running some software (though it would be nice!), but losing the ability for people to easily open an issue seems like a major loss

I suppose you could always wire something up where they just send an email and it automatically creates an issue under some bot account, but then you have to do a ton of work to let them reply to further interaction? kinda meh

but at a high level it would be nice to move off of github onto something decentralized where contributors can do the things they want to do locally and have it all cryptographically signed and offline-but-synced, but also let those who just want to do more drive-by contributions do so in a more traditional manner (bonus points if its via github and just bridged to the other platform!)

even moving to a self-hosted platform has the major disadvantage (or advantage, depending on the project lol) that opening an issue requires someone signing up for yet another account which can definitely prevent issues from being reported.

but if radicle had a user option it would be a pretty trivial patch to just let people submit issues after passing a recaptcha check or whatever, which would be even better cause no account needed (and you just store a cookie to let them reply as long as its the same machine)

Oh, I could have been more clear. I'm doing a reset similar to how process_message(s) resets the chainman with ResetChainman, except I make a new mempool as well. I have to reset the global rng at the end of the test before I make a new mempool because of the SaltedTxidHasher / SaltedWtxidHasher

If I don't reset the rng at the end of the test, then I get non-determinism in the next iterations since these hashers are seeded with values from a "dirty" rng

threads.first_message: <darosior> "i know she's been keeping..." <- there was a time i was actively watching radicle. at the time it was far from usable for any kind of real project with many contributors. it's been a while

<laanwj> "also they started using some..." <- Afaiu they basically issued a token then took the money to fund development and have now removed any connection to the token lol. Kinda scammy but I guess
BlueMatt[m]: Have you considered self-hosting gitlab? It's a bit overkill for sure but works pretty well if someone is willing to do the maintenance, probably doable with 1-2h per month.
Guess Qt doesn’t want to build against the new SDK 🥲

<fjahr> "Matt Corallo: Have you considere..." <- probably more likely gitea than gitlab, looks cleaner and much simpler to self-host, but I'm wayyyyy more excited to use something that has built-in cr
it looks designed for a situation where every contributor runs their own radicle node, so you can use node key as user identifier, and give permission based on those?

BlueMatt[m] I agree, I think it would be nice to use something "decentralized", since that should be important to contributers here (and other bitcoin projects).
I think it's sort of interesting the aproach here: https://bitcoinbackbone.org/
where it's just a web page that uses Git, since Git itself is a very decentralized by design.
Although, it lacks a good way as you mention to deal with issues and discuss Merge Requests.
Radical looks interesting, but without a critical mass of people interested in running nodes, it feels overkill in someway
If there was a simple webui that handled Merge Requests (PRs) and Issues added to bitcoinbackbone.org, that would be an interesting prototype
I'm not sure what more you need.  And also some CI infrastructure on the backend.
that isn't a "source forge", that's just access to someone's repo. adding PRs and issues and issue/PR moderation and code reviews is the whole complexity bit!
Yeah I agre, I'm just thinking about ways that aren't just email patches to and fro, because that is the most bare-bones decentralized verion.
It feels like a way to bolt on a forum board to a website that points to a Git location would suffice to do PR/issue mederation.
s/agre/agree
s/mederation/moderation
sorry for typos, was half asleep still I guesss
something like radicle seems much better than something hacky like that? assuming they get a few further updates.

not that I can ever get anyone to review my PRs on this repo anyway xD
Actually though, would probably be better to test out something like radicle on a smaller project first

The discussion of switching to a decentralized alternative to Github seems to have moved on.  Although, I'd like to also add that I think looking at the threat-model should help decide what aspect of a Github alternative should be evaluated.
In my observation, Github seems to be a threat in moderating forum posts with actions like banning Draftbot for example
Which is why I suggest some self moderated version of a forum that is locally hosted

hebasto: our vcpkg caching in CI looks a bit busted to me. It seems to take ~40 mins each run, with virtually no cache hits, e.g. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/actions/runs/21136611582/job/60780035656?pr=34296#step:9:281 Can we fix the cache keys to hit better somehow? Or perhaps we should investigate something like

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/vcpkg/consume/binary-caching-github-packages?pivots=windows-runner ? I'm afraid I'm such a windows n00b I don't really know whats going wrong to know which approach might be best to look at first :(
willcl-ark: i'll take a look
thanks!
